comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Yes, Number 8 to be precise. Is that where the Mitchell Library now is? The new Lending Branch premises opened in August 1881, so presumably this photo and the others in the series of how it was built are earlier that year. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13493005

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Definitely Macquarie Street! You can see the turrets of the Hospital building further up the road. Today 8 Macquarie is the address of the Eye Hospital.... www.sesiahs.health.nsw.gov.au/sydhosp/ - AG

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: This is the Iron Church which housed the Lending Library from 1874 after the congregation outgrew it and moved across the road to present day St Stephens. There is a plaque on the footpath outside the current State Reference Library wing remembering the Iron Church. www.gordonmoyes.com/2007/10/25/iron-churches/
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] Thank you, that makes a lot more sense. These must be photos of the dismantling of the library/church, before its rebuilding at Lidcombe Hospital as a chapel in 1879. The other photos in the series - and the rebuilding at Lidcombe (on Flickr) - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6104228197/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Google Maps Street view comparison - g.co/maps/azwm

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: WAIT UP! The 1879 dismantling date is WRONG ! More likely to be 1899. A search of Trove for "iron church" produces conflicting reports, but most of the contemporary letters and articles mention it still being used as a Lending Library up to 1899. (It was also a tweed cloth factory for a while before being a library). It is the later reports in the 1930s and 1950s which give the erroneous 1879 date. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14228725 Also the Sydney Hospital building in the background was not completed until 1894 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney_Hospital#The_Central_Building . And I think there are way too many telephone wires for 1879. So 1899? And from the amazing perspectives, use of the telephone wires for emphasis, and the style of the title, I bet it is the work of John Degotardi Jnr.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Report in the SMH of 16/6/1899 describing the recent closure of the Macquarie Street Library and the imminent opening of a new Library on the 2nd floor of the Queen Victoria Markets (QVB), under the supervision of the Government Architect's Department - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14236876
